This application was developed by Stefania-Bianca Costache and Nashwan-Mouhammad Azhari, two students from the University "Politehnica" of Timisoara, as part of their practical assignment for the subject entitled "Computer Organization"; all under the exquisite guidance of Professor Mircea Udrescu, the course's head lecturer, and Professor Alexandru Topirceanu, the one in charge of the laboratory hours, for whose respective involvements we are thoroughly in debt. 

Entitled simply "DroidPI", a name derived from the very first benchmark we have ever written, this application aims to serve a narrow but significant nieche: that of the simple, straightforward and non-invasive benchmarking of Android devices.
We focused on four major benchmarks, each one designed specifically to test a certain performance aspect of your device's CPU.
Although, as some may argue, rudimentary, DroidPI offers the quickest approach to gauging your phone's real world computational capabilities without requiring any sort of permissions apart from that of basic running.

The benchmarked algorithms (the computation of the digits of PI, the use of numerous threads for the obtaining of a square root, the incessant recursive calling of the same function for finding more and more primes and the repeated execution of a handful of arithmetic operations) were all adapted for use in our project by Stefania, whilst the overall design and implementation of the application itself was done by Nashwan.

As far as the scoring system goes:
All of the benchmarks are run and their respective execution times are measured in an utmost isolative manner, the application then offering the results in milliseconds, as well as a per 100 score which relates your result to the scores obtained by the Samsung Galaxy S4, arguably one of the most powerful phones on the market upon this application's inception.
 Now granted, due to numerous outside influences the final assessed score may vary, even exceeding 100 in the case of higher end phones. The shortcomings of the scoring system were part of the compromise of making the application as transparent and non-invasive as possible whilst still offering a tangible result apart from a time measurement /n/n As the authors, we would like to thank you for trying out the application. Although it may seem insignificant to you, the making of this greatly contributed to the skillsets and overall awareness of the developers and vastly broadened their knowledge of the working of hardware benchmarking, an activity we hope to partake in again in the near future.

If you have (surprisingly) stayed with us this long, and because we are firm advocates of the Open-Source model, we would like to welcome you to view, analyse, fork and freely use the source code for this application, which can be found in full Android Studio Gradle project form at /n
